Article Title: WhatsApp, Google and other OTT companies to Airtel, Reliance Jio, Vodafone-Idea: Your views are misplaced and ...
Article Text:
What is the Big Fight over

The Telecom Regulatory Authority of India ( TRAI ) is facing a tug-of-war between telecom operators and the tech industry as it seeks to tighten regulations against spam and online scams. At a recent open house discussion, telecom operators advocated for bringing OTT platforms and businesses under stricter regulatory oversight, arguing that these entities often contribute significantly to spam but escape accountability.However, the Broadband India Forum (BIF), representing tech companies, countered that OTT platforms are already regulated under the Information Technology Act and additional oversight by TRAI is unnecessary.The debate centers around the Telecom Commercial Communications Customer Preference Regulations (TCCCPR), 2018, which are being reviewed to enhance spam prevention measures. Telcos emphasize that OTT platforms, which carry a substantial portion of commercial traffic, must be included in the regulatory framework to effectively combat spam.BIF, on the other hand, maintains that TCCCPR primarily applies to telecom service providers and not OTT platforms. Debashish Bhattacharya, senior deputy director-general at BIF, reportedly called the telco’s comments as “misplaced and legally untenable” and said the TCCCPR applied to access service providers and not OTT platforms.TRAI Chairman AK Lahoti acknowledged the diverse viewpoints and assured that the regulator would consider all perspectives while finalizing the new regulations. He also commended the telecom industry's efforts to curb spam.Telcos argue that all entities involved in communication services, including OTT platforms and telemarketers, should be held accountable for spam and bear the costs associated with unsolicited commercial communications (UCC). They point out that while they act as intermediaries, they are often solely responsible for financial penalties related to spam, despite the content being generated by others. “There should not be more subjective restrictions on telecom firms. PEs and telemarketers should be held accountable,” Vodafone Idea’s regulatory head Ambika Khurana said.To address this issue, telcos have proposed that telemarketers and business entities share the responsibility for spam and face financial penalties. They also emphasize the need for greater transparency in the message delivery chain to identify the origin and aggregation of spam messages.“There are disproportionate levels of financial disincentive on telcos. Accountability has to be levied on PEs and telemarketers and not only on telcos,” UK Srivastava, President at Reliance Jio added.Bharti Airtel regulatory head Rahul Vatts said when the issue is spam, how could there be a distinction wherein one platform where the message is coming is regulated but the other is not. “If you are really concerned about spam, you should be more than happy to willingly agree with Trai’s gold standard to curb spam,” Vatts argued, adding that “the IT rules do not specifically cover the point of UCC as there is a broad definition but nothing specific to UCC”.
Article Summary: The Telecom Regulatory Authority of India is facing a tug-of-war between telecom operators and the tech industry. The debate centers around the Telecom Commercial Communications Customer Preference Regulations (TCCCPR), 2018. Telcos argue that all entities involved in communication services, including OTT platforms and telemarketers, should be held accountable for spam.

We should scale solar so much more, amazing that we keep looking at alternatives when the most obvious path is staring at our eyes, literally!,” said Pichai.The new "Willow" quantum chip demonstrates unprecedented error correction capabilities, a critical challenge that has stymied quantum computing researchers for decades. With 105 qubits, the chip can reduce computational errors exponentially as it scales up, a feat scientists have pursued since the 1990s.In a groundbreaking demonstration, Google's quantum researchers showed the Willow chip could complete a computational task in roughly five minutes that would require a classical supercomputer an estimated 10 septillion (10^25) years—far exceeding the known age of the universe.

Article Title: US Justice Department opposes TikTok's plea: “...continued Chinese control of the TikTok app poses…”

TikTok has argued that the incoming Trump administration, which has expressed opposition to the ban, should have time to review the situation.US President-elect Donald Trump provided an unclear stance on the TikTok ban at an interview by avoiding committing to saving TikTok though he hinted that ByteDance should divest the platform.When asked whether he will act to protect the app, Trump said, “This week a federal court upheld a law that could result in TikTok being banned. You said you're going to rescue TikTok when you get into office. Are you going to take steps to protect it?," Trump said in reply.The fate of TikTok now hangs in the balance, with US President Joe Biden potentially able to grant a 90-day extension to the divestiture deadline. Article Title: Will Google's Willow quantum computing chip means risk for Bitcoin? Here's what you need to know
Article Text:

Google has achieved a major breakthrough in quantum computing with the unveiling of its next-generation chip, Willow. According to Google, the Willow chip can solve intricate problems in under five minutes—calculations so complex they would take a supercomputer approximately 10 septillion years (10^25) to complete. Despite its extraordinary capabilities, experts have reassured that Bitcoin and other cryptographic systems remain secure.“The Willow chip is a major step on a journey that began over 10 years ago,” Hartmut Neven, VP engineering at Google said in a blog post. Neven is vice president of engineering at Google. He is the founder and manager of the Quantum Artificial Intelligence lab, said to be behind this breakthrough.Following the introduction of Willow, there have been murmurs that Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies could be on the way out. Some are wondering: Could this new chip pose a threat to Bitcoin’s famously strong encryption?The crypto community's response to Willow's launch has been mixed. Some express concerns about long-term security risks, while others maintain that current quantum technology poses no immediate threat. Some experts suggest proactive measures, like freezing vulnerable holdings or implementing expiration dates for outdated cryptographic standards, as precautionary steps.While Willow represents a major advancement, it's not powerful enough to crack Bitcoin's encryption. Experts estimate that millions of qubits would be required to compromise Bitcoin's security, far surpassing Willow's current capacity of 105 qubits. Additionally, quantum computers need stable and error-free qubits over extended periods, a challenge that current technology, including Willow, hasn't fully addressed.https://x.com/LacasiaPablo/status/1866236477853880398Despite the hype surrounding quantum computing, Bitcoin's underlying cryptographic algorithms remain robust. Experts emphasize that Willow's capabilities, though impressive, are not sufficient to jeopardize Bitcoin's security.
Article Summary: Google has unveiled its next-generation quantum computing chip, Willow. The chip can solve complex problems in under five minutes. Willow is not powerful enough to crack Bitcoin's encryption. Experts say Willow's capabilities are not sufficient to jeopardize Bitcoin's security.

The US Supreme Court has dismissed Nvidia's appeal in a securities fraud lawsuit. This will allow the company’s shareholders to proceed with their case against the AI chipmaker. The lawsuit accuses Nvidia of misleading investors about its dependence on the cryptocurrency market. The court declined to intervene in the legal dispute, leaving a lower court's ruling in place that permitted the 2018 class action lawsuit to move forward.The lawsuit focuses on whether Nvidia violated the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act , a 1995 law aimed at preventing frivolous lawsuits. The Supreme Court's dismissal came without explanation, the report noted.During the hearing, several justices expressed reservations about their involvement in the case, citing concerns about the lack of a clear legal issue and the technical complexities involved.In this lawsuit, the shareholders accused Nvidia and its CEO Jensen Huang of violating the 1934 Securities Exchange Act. They alleged that in 2017 and 2018, Nvidia downplayed how much of its revenue growth was driven by cryptocurrency-related purchases.As cryptocurrency prices surged, Nvidia's chips became popular for crypto mining in 2017. However, when crypto profitability declined in 2018, Nvidia's revenue fell short of projections, causing its stock price to drop.The lawsuit seeks unspecified monetary damages to compensate investors for their losses. While Nvidia paid $5.5 million in 2022 to settle charges related to its disclosures about crypto mining's impact on its gaming business, it did not admit or deny wrongdoing.A federal judge initially dismissed the shareholder lawsuit, but the 9th US Circuit Court of Appeals revived it, stating the plaintiffs had sufficiently alleged that Huang made "false or misleading statements and did so knowingly or recklessly."The shareholders' lawyer, Deepak Gupta, called the Supreme Court's dismissal “a win for corporate accountability.”Gupta added.What Nvidia said about the US Supreme Court’s decisionThe company is "fully prepared to continue our defence," an Nvidia spokesperson said."Consistent and predictable standards in securities litigation are essential to protecting shareholders and ensuring a strong economy, and we remain committed to supporting them," the spokesperson noted.Nvidia argued that the shareholders' lawsuit lacked sufficient evidence to prove false statements or intentional deception. Meanwhile, the shareholders countered that their allegations, supported by various sources including former employees and market analysis, were strong enough to proceed to the discovery phase.
Article Summary: The US Supreme Court has dismissed Nvidia's appeal in a securities fraud lawsuit. This will allow the company’s shareholders to proceed with their case against the AI chipmaker. The lawsuit accuses Nvidia of misleading investors about its dependence on the cryptocurrency market.

Article Title: ChatGPT back after global outage
Article Text: OpenAI has successfully restored services for its popular chatbot, ChatGPT, following a major global outage on Thursday morning. This disruption extended beyond ChatGPT, affecting OpenAI's API, a critical tool for developers, and Sora, another AI-powered service.ChatGPT creator OpenAI has acknowledged the issue and has also posted about the same on X (formerly known as Twitter). “We're experiencing an outage right now. We have identified the issue and are working to roll out a fix. Sorry and we'll keep you updated!,” posted the company.The services are now restored and users are able to access ChatGPT and other OpenAI services.

Article Title: Google Gemini 2.0 launch: CEO Sundar Pichai says, “I’m especially excited to see...”
Article Text:
We’re kicking off the start of our Gemini 2.0 era with Gemini 2.0 Flash, which outperforms 1.5 Pro on key benchmarks at 2X speed (see chart below). I’m especially excited to see the fast progress on coding, with more to come.

Developers can try an experimental version in AI Studio and Vertex AI today. It is also available to try in @GeminiApp on the web today, mobile coming soon.

We are investing in the frontiers of agentic capabilities with a few early prototypes. Project Mariner is built with Gemini 2.0 and is able to understand and reason across information - pixels, text, code, images + forms - on your browser screen, and then uses that info to complete tasks for you.

Gemini 2.0 in AI Overviews

Google has unveiled Gemini 2.0, an advanced AI model designed for the 'agentic' era. This model powers AI agents—intelligent assistants capable of taking actions and executing tasks on behalf of users. Among its applications, Google introduced Jules, an AI agent that can independently code, diagnose issues, and resolve them, as well as Project Mariner , which can perform various tasks on the web.Google launched AI Overviews – AI generated summaries on topics that require research. Pichai said that the company is bringing the capabilities of Gemini 2.0 to AI Overviews that have reached 1 billion people and continue to bring AI Overviews to more countries and languages over the next year.Google has already started limited testing and will be rolling it out more broadly early next year.“No product has been transformed more by AI than Search. Our AI Overviews now reach 1 billion people, enabling them to ask entirely new types of questions — quickly becoming one of our most popular Search features ever. As a next step, we’re bringing the advanced reasoning capabilities of Gemini 2.0 to AI Overviews to tackle more complex topics and multi-step questions, including advanced math equations, multimodal queries and coding,” Pichai added.
Article Summary: Google has unveiled Gemini 2.0, an advanced AI model designed for the 'agentic' era.
